awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Theory and Practice of Cryptosystems Secure Against Subversion
awd_abstract_narration:
The discipline of cryptography provides the basic digital tools used across the globe to ensure data privacy and authenticity. With the broad deployment of these tools--often invisibly embedded in commercial software or hardware--an unconventional but devastating type of cyberattacks have emerged. These attacks involve deploying a cleverly subverted version of a cryptographic tool that appears to function normally, but in fact deliberately reduces security in a covert way that is known only to the subverting party. Such an attack can be carried out by the author of a software package, the manufacturer of a hardware device, or a third party who has contrived to interfere with the deployed product. Recent high-profile incidents of this kind have highlighted the threat associated with these attacks. This project is a comprehensive study of security in this setting, including development of formal models that permit rigorous reasoning about security, design and analysis of new cryptographic tools that resist subversion, and explicit recommendations for hardening the existing cryptographic tools in widespread use.

The project is organized into three main threads. The first focuses on establishing cryptographic security models that expand on classical cryptographic models to adequately reflect malicious subversion attacks: in general, these models call for the design of cryptographic tools to be explicitly coupled with specification of black-box testing procedures so that the combination can guarantee security despite subversion attacks. The second effort pursues development of fundamental cryptographic primitives that achieve security in these new models and application of these primitives as building blocks to construct larger systems and protocols that retain security despite subversion. Finally, to transition these theoretical tools to practice, the project undertakes a practical effort to re-architect existing infrastructural tools, such as the IPSec, SSH and TLS protocols, to harden them against subversion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has focused on securing cryptographic and cybersecurity infrastructure against a new breed of cyberattacks that involve malicious subversion of the elementary cryptographic algorithms that are embedded into devices such as smartphones and network routers. While such attacks require bad actors at the level of manufacturers or cryptographic algorithm designers, they are very powerful: in particular, there are simple instances where a deployed algorithm can appear to be faithfully implemented under blackbox testing but still enable devastating attacks. While the security community has been aware of the (theoretical) possibility of such attacks for decades, several high-profile appearances in practice have led to renewed interest in modeling and securing against such risks.

These concerns inform the primary goals of the project: rigorous modeling of subversion attacks, development of general methods for immunizing cryptographic algorithms against these attacks, and explicit constructions of cryptographic building blocks that can be used to construct a portfolio of tools that are secure against subversion. The project developed an analogue of an existing cryptographic security framework called "indifferentiability" in order to express security in this model: this has the advantage that it provides a direct means for arguing about the security that results from combining mutiple cryptographic primitives into more complex cryptographic mechanisms. The project then developed secure constructions of two critical cryptographic primitives in this setting: a cryptographic hash function and a symmetric encryption algorithm. The project also developed techniques to support more powerful notions of encryption.

While it is natural to expect that progress on subversion-secure cryptography will eventually be reflected in real-world implementations of cryptography, the project also focused on some topics in post-election auditing that share some analytic commonalities and will have more immediate societal impacts. In particular, the project developed new techniques and models for risk-limiting auditing, the standard framework for verifying the correctness of large-scale elections. These audits compare the tabulated results of an election (which includes a ballot-by-ballot indication of cast votes) against a statistical sample of phyical ballots in order to detect discrepancies. While these audits can provide powerful mathematical guarantees, they have not been widely adopted due to complexity and cost. The project has pursued two new approaches that can reduce the sample size necessary for confident auditing: the first method reduces the work that needs to be done for batches of ballots that are not ultimately selected for audit; the second improves the statistical power of the tests by permitting tabulations to include data about ambiguous marks on ballots.
